posts.title: Unsung History of the Kingdom of Kongo
posts.text: The history of the kingdom is one that shows the sophistication, political, military, technological, and economical advancement and structure of this African kingdom.

posts.title: Kimpa Vita of the Kingdom of Kongo: Embodiment of Resistance
posts.text: Kimpa Vita's life exemplifies resistance to Europeans’ invasion and colonization of Africa.

posts.title: Josephine Turpin Washington: Relative of Thomas Jefferson and Clerk for Frederick Douglass
posts.text: Washington was a teacher and writer who advocated for the rights of Black women in the 19th century.

posts.title: Flora Batson Bergen: A Voice That Fought Racial Prejudice in the 19th Century
posts.text: She toured the world and was considered by many to be the greatest concert singer of the 19th century.

posts.title: Understanding Robert Douglass’s Reshaping of Visual Narrative About Black People in 19th Century America from a Multiliteracies Perspective
posts.text: The work of artist and activist Robert Douglas Jr. served two purposes: reclaiming Black identity among Black people, while countering popular narratives about Blacks in the collective minds of Americans.

posts.title: John Gassett: First Black Owner of a Grocery Store in Cartersville, Georgia
posts.text: With his grocery store, he provided his community with essentials needed for daily living; as a real estate developer, he addressed housing issues; and without doubt, his political engagement was driven by the interests of the Black community.

posts.title: Colonel John McKee: Wealthiest African American At His Death in 1902
posts.text: The greatest legacy of Colonel John McKee is to have dared, and have succeeded in a business area in which Blacks were nonexistent in the 19th century.

posts.title: Alexander Crummell, Episcopalian Priest, Cambridge University Graduate
posts.text: His writings, sermons, speeches, and other literary works were avenues he employed to reclaim Black identity, and oppose narratives about the inferiority of the Black race.

posts.title: Considering Flora Stewart’s Portrait as an Autobiography of an African American Woman
posts.text: “A picture is worth a thousand words”

posts.title: Flora Stewart: African American Woman, Oldest Citizen of Londonderry, N.H
posts.text: She was an enslaved woman who lived more than 100 years, and even in her old age had tremendous mental, physical, and intellectual abilities.

posts.title: Robert Douglass Jr., 19th Century African American Artist
posts.text: First post of a series exploring lesser-known 19th century African Americans who in various ways fought to reclaim Black identity, and humanity, and contributed to the struggle for freedom.
